pros: Amazing colleagues and beautiful location.
cons: The high cost of living (e.g., housing, food).

pros: Location, Location Location (Bend Campus)
cons: The pay rate for adjuncts is below poverty level,the admin / deans cut classes before the students have a chance to meet with advisors so can't enroll and the adjuncts get stuck scrambling trying to make ends meet in one of the most expensive towns in the U.S. The administration from the top town is a train wreck, only caring about filling classes with too many students (bottom line) and have little to no concern about the health, safety, well being and financial sustainability of the faculty. In over 20 years of teaching in higher ed all around the country, this was by far the worst place I have ever taught. Too many negatives to list.

pros: - good benefits - time off - work life balance
cons: - low pay - little upward movement - red tape

review_title: gas lit into thinking this was a good place to work
pros: students co-workers discount massage clinic tuition waiver pto
cons: poverty wage non-responsive & non-supportive management limited to no advancement opportunity tendency to overload staff with no extra support or compensation for a college they have no respect for employees with college degrees Inflexible time off policy so it's difficult to use vacation

pros: People are really nice and helpful, and encouraging.
cons: $625 per unit for Professors. Really terrible. OSU-Cascades starts their Professors out at $1000 per unit.

pros: The people you work with are amazing and most people will say that is the best thing about COCC. I have experienced work/life balance but it does depend on your department. Typically, low stress work environment compared to other colleges I have worked at. Beautiful place to work.
cons: Low pay and bureaucracy are usually the biggest complaints. Staff get 3% raises each year.

review_title: Fantastic People, cannot afford to work here.
pros: Great Community, beautiful location, you get to work with some outstanding people.
cons: Does not pay enough to live in Bend, OR. *Not necessarily their fault, Bend is now insanely expensive, you almost already have to be wealthy to live here.

review_title: Good environment, Good co-workers, Great boss
job_title: Computer Lab Assistant in Bend, OR
pros: It was an easy job if you know even the most basic part of computers. Mix that with a boss that does his absolute best for his employees and you get a really good student job.
cons: Only 10 hours a week with a starting pay of minimum wage

pros: Very friendly staff and a supportive community
cons: Pandemic handling could have been handled better

pros: Location...Bend is beautiful. They call it "Poverty with a View" which is sadly accurate for the teachers at COCC.
cons: Too many to list. Poverty level pay for part time/adjuncts, no contacts, NO respect or value from administration, sickeningly bad communication and organization from the top down, constantly cancelling classes weeks before the term starts due to "low enrollment" but not allowing students enough time to register...especially on the satellite campuses, lack of safety and concern for faculty safety in and outside of classrooms, reckless and short-sighted behavior during the COVID-19 pandemic in how to proceed into the fall/winter 2020/2021. DO NOT teach here unless you enjoy being treated like a slave, overworked, underpaid (especially given the cost of living in Bend) and constantly living in fear for having classes cancelled and slipping further into debt while working more than 30 hours a week with a terminal degree and more than 20 years of teaching experience. From a student's point of view the school is a total organizational nightmare. THE WORST school I've ever taught at, and I've taught all around the country.

review_title: classified staff are worth more than they are paid.
pros: Lots of really good people. Union representation for classified employees and the ability to negotiate every 1-3 years. Many opportunities to be active and engaged with the college community. Benefits include PERS, about 3 weeks pto per year, tuition waiver for employees, spouses, and dependents, medical, dental, vision.
cons: Raises rarely keep pace with cost of living expenses, on average 2-3%. Internal hires who have been promoted will usually start their new position at a lower wage than brand new hires in the same salary grade, and internal hires do not get a raise at the 6 month mark while new hires will get a 3% raise after finishing their probationary period. Pay is lousy when compared to the cost of living in central oregon, particularly with regard to housing. Many of my full time coworkers recieve public assistance or work multiple jobs to make ends meet.

pros: Awesome co-workers, work-life balance, beautiful campus
cons: too many meetings and working in silos

pros:
co-workers are supportive, kind and work extremely hard, particularly classified employees, who do most of the heavy lifting. 

students are fun to work with
cons: Professional growth is extremely difficult in this environment. Qualified workers are passed over for promotion while those who fit the image/aesthetic of "the college" (i.e., attractive, young and white) are hired/promoted even without experience or qualifications. Management tends to like candidates who are easily manipulated and made to back questionable initiatives/pet projects. Men tend to move up the ladder much more quickly, although there are plenty of females in administration. However, even female administrators tend to be fairly misogynistic. Students are an afterthought to administrative ego, which must be stroked at all times. Many many many many fruitless meetings, involving highly paid professionals, that typically take up enormous amounts of time and are usually not effective nor meaningful.

review_title: Can be a good place to work
pros: I worked for a department that had great leadership and we were treated great by our boss. You get sick leave and vacation and can use them easily.
cons: No way to get promoted and upper management above each department run like its 1960.  Pay sucked- professionalism expectations high considering the low pay grade level.  Upper management had no idea what it was like for the peeons who had to live on poverty wages and refused to give raises other than the mandated by union penny anty raises.

pros: Benefits are decent, pay is not. Some great people.
cons: Disconnected management and often hired or promoted with little or no direct experience in the field. Problematic all around, especially when they lack incentive to learn or listen; empower staff. Lines of communication can be extremely poor in some departments. Ask about management experience and style before taking a job. Part-time, adjunct and classified tread carefully. Varies widely from department to department. Some managers are uniformed, disconnected and punitive by nature.

pros: Diverse experiences, management/staff is very flexible with scheduling, everyone is very sincere on helping students learn. Pay was competitive to state universities.
cons: Sometimes students you're tutoring don't realize that they're being condescending and rude, and more should be done to express that this kind of behavior to unfair to sincere tutors.

pros: Challenging job, good pay for having an entry level job in college.
cons: Not always a lot of hours, priority to students who have government work study so that way the college doesn't have to pay the employee, the government does.

review_title: it is a great place to work and go to school
pros: it is a really low key job, it works around my class schedule and I have a rad boss.
cons: the hours fluctuate a lot, not very many hours some months.

review_title: Typical higher ed - great benefits but lots of bureacracy
pros: great benefits, awesome co-workers, beautiful campus
cons: higher ed moves at a glacial pace, though this is a smaller community college so decision-making isn't too weighted down, there is still a lot of bureaucracy to wade through

pros: The people you work with are very friendly and passionate about their work. Great benefits and work environment.
cons: It does get boring at times during the slower times of terms. Once you complete work, there isn't too much more to do.

review_title: Reactionary, poor management with virtually no team atmosphere
pros: Great location and quality of life in Bend, OR.
cons:
Very little teamwork.
Reactionary management.
Adversarial climate among Directors and upper management.
Hypocrisy abounds!

pros: Great city, lots of outdoor activities, friendly people, excellent instructors, growing aviation program
cons: School is on side of hill so when it snows or gets icy, driving is tough,

pros: The instructors are self motivated, strive to be innovative, and they care about their students.
cons: Change can be slow in coming.
